title: former-cockenzie-power-station-site-about-to-be-put-on-open-market
story: East Lothian Council is preparing to put giant signs on the former Cockenzie Power Station land inviting potential customers to make a bid.The move comes just over a year after the council formally completed the purchase of the -acre coastline site.Public consultations on the future of the site, which includes a large area of communal land, known as the Greenhills, which is used by local communities and the former coal plant site and historic Waggonway land, were carried out over two years ago.The local authority produced a masterplan for the site based on the consultations, which it described as a ldquovision document for its future.However, neighbouring communities straddling the site have opposing views on its best future development.Prestonpans Community Council has lobbied for a cruise terminal at the former power station and the council has agreed to carry out an engineering study into its feasibility.In neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton, community councillors are keen to see the masterplan, which does not support a cruise port, adopted by the local authority.It sets out a range of ideas for the site, including the potential for a marina at the waterfront, business and economic sectors, and recreational land.Despite the investment into producing the masterplan and consulting the public, the only definite project confirmed for the site so far is an unmanned substation, which will bring offshore energy onto land for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd .ICOL, which are owned by Chinese State-owned company Red Rock, was granted permission for the substation after the Scottish Ministers called in its planning application shortly after East Lothian Council bought the land.The council confirmed earlier this month that is had agreed to sell part of the land to ICOL.A bid by local group the Battle of Prestonpans Heritage Trust to buy part of the land for its own heritable project has been rejected by the council.The council told the trust it had been advised against selling until ldquosuch time as the future of the whole site has been determined.Signs promoting the land for development are expected to go up on the site within the next few weeks after they were given planning approval.They will invite all enquiries about ldquoeconomic development opportunities on the site to get in touch via email.

title: port-seton-woman-receives-maundy-purse-from-the-queen
story: Dorothy Tervit was presented the purse of specially minted coins by Her Majesty The Queen at a ceremony before Easter weekend.Dorothy, from Laburnum Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoWhen the invitation came through in November, I thought it was a hoax!ldquoI thought lsquowhy on earth would Buckingham Palace be writing to me rsquoThe -year-old, who is a member of the local community choir, the local history society and Chalmers Memorial Church, was nominated by an anonymous supporter.The nominator has to be a Christian minister and the recipient is not allowed to know their identity, though Dorothy has some ideas.She said: ldquoUsing the process of elimination, I could make an educated guess.ldquoIrsquom so grateful, though, as the whole experience was absolutely wonderful ndash a real once-in-a-letime moment.The Royal Maundy refers to the service where the British Monarch distributes small purses full of coins called Maundy money as symbolic alms to the nominated recipients. It is a ceremony thought to date back to the Middle Ages and took place at St Georgersquos Chapel in Windsor.The coins are presented in two leather purses, a white one containing coins to the value of the same number of pence as the years of the monarchrsquos age, and a red purse containing a pound and a p coin.Dorothy was one of  recipients. As the Queen is  years old, there are  female recipients and  male recipients, as well as  pence worth of special silver coins in one of the purses.The other purse presented included a commemorative pound coin marking the th anniversary of Queen Victoriarsquos birth.Dorothy attended the ceremony last week with her husband Tom.She added: ldquoThe Queen was so gracious, I felt undeserving. We werenrsquot allowed to speak to her, as per the rules, but she had such a warm smile for everyone in line for the purse.

title: worlds-oldest-golf-scorecard-from-musselburgh-up-for-auction
story: Estimated at pound,-,, the card, which has been framed and mounted, dates from December , .It shows that a Mr Cundell played the five holes within the Musselburgh race track twice, a total of  holes in  strokes. Charmingly, the golfer provided his own commentary in a handwritten note at the bottom of the card: ldquoDreadful storm of wind and rain ndash atmosphere quite yellow ndash just like the lurid regions of Pandemonium.Mr Cundell is almost certainly James Cundell, who was closely involved with the Thistle Golf Club since its founding in  and who published one of the first ever rule books of golf in .Kevin McGimpsey, Bonhamsrsquo golfing memorabilia consultant, said: ldquoThis original scorecard is in remarkable condition considering its age and the atrocious weather conditions at the time Mr Cundell played his round.ldquoIt has an excellent provenance, having once belonged to the well-known golfer Sir Henry Cotton, who kept it in his renowned Black Tin Box with other rare examples of historical golfing memorabilia.ldquoThe scorecard predates the oldest cards owned by the international golf museums.The scorecard will be auctioned at Bonhamsrsquo next sporting sale at its  Queen Street saleroom on Wednesday, which will present Part II of The Pierre Horwitz Collection of golfing memorabilia. This covers the period from the early part of the th century to the s and concentrates especially on the manufacture of clubs and balls and rare patented designs of both.Other highlights include: a white painted feather golf ball, handmade in about  by Allan Robertson, one of the most gted of the early professional golfers and a long nosed scared neck putter from about - made by Robert Forgan. The Pierre Horwitz collection Part I made a total of pound, last October.Documentary evidence proves that golf was played on Musselburgh Links as early as  although Mary, Queen of Scots reputedly played there in .

title: rocket-firm-hopes-to-test-engines-at-former-power-station-site
story: Skyrora has revealed it has identied part of the old Cockenzie Power Station site as a location for its test site.The company, which describes itself as a launch vehicle development company with aims to cater for the growing demand to send small satellites into space, is expected to apply for planning permission from East Lothian Council within the next few months.It held a public consultation on its proposals at the Port Seton Centre today .The Courier revealed last August that Skyrora were looking at East Lothian sites, with the former power station one of the possibilities it was considering to test its rocket engines.Skyrora said that the engine testing would not involve the launching of rockets from the site but would require fuel to be stored on-site to fire up the engines.The UK Space Agency announced that it was investing millions of pounds in a site in Sutherland as the new home of the UKrsquos first spaceport for launching rockets.Skyrora said it was looking for an engine test site within an hour of its Edinburgh offices to give it a local base.It said it had identied part of the former power station site, which was bought by East Lothian Council last year, for its tests.The area being put forward for the site is part of the old coal store.Skyrora said: ldquoThe site will be protected, and special measures will be undertaken to control down the noise impacts to acceptable levels and minimal-period test events.Last year it was revealed that Glasgow produced more space satellites than any other city outside of the USA.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have been in discussions with Skyrora about the possibility of a temporary lease of land for activities based around engine testing.ldquoA planning application would need to be submitted by Skyrora and considered in due course.

title: dog-walkers-surprise-at-coming-across-octopus-on-beach-at-musselburgh
story: Shona Grieve, , from Longniddry, who now lives in the Fisherrow area, was taking her two-year-old white German shepherd Ivy for her regular walk on the beach when she saw the dead creature.She said: "I was walking at the Fisherrow end of the beach beside the the bowling green."I had thrown Ivys ball and walked to where the ball landed and saw the octopus."I walk the beach every day, sometimes three times a day, with Ivy. In all the years of living by the sea, I have never seen an octopus before. So for me it was a very unusual find. Ivy was a bit curious of it too but more interested in her ball to be fair."She added: "I kept ing to it, to convince myself it was dead which it definitely was."The sea was far out but to reassure myself I managed to put it in a pool of water. This was early on and there was nobody  about to show so I took a picture."I have since been told it is getting more common to find them. I had never seen one before ndash my only rare sighting on the beach was when I was a child and found a small pool of seahorses."An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: "The lesser octopus is not that common but they do turn up occasionally, cast up especially after a storm or following prolonged rough weather."Live specimens have also been found in rock pools at the lowest part of the beach."

title: honest-lad-and-honest-lass-2019-elected
story: A large crowd, including representatives from the Border towns, gathered to hear the election announcement, which was made from the outside balcony at The Brunton at about pm on Friday.The new Honest Lad and Honest Lass were presented with their medals of office by this yearrsquos sasher PC Dougie Smith, youth community officer.The announcement followed a public election earlier in the day, prior to which the only other candidate for Honest Lad, Michael Morrison, was disbarred from standing due to a pending court case for allegedly using a car without insurance.Aidan, , and Claire, , who was an attendant last year, made their way to an open carriage and, along with the attendant for  Abbie Thomson,  ndash who had stood as an Honest Lass candidate ndash they were piped through the town by the Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band. Volunteers from Musselburgh Sea Cadets had the honour of pulling the carriage.The official party then made its way to Musselburgh Rugby Club to join well-wishers. In keeping with tradition, they danced an eightsome reel with support from th anniversary Attendants Carol Colville and David Banks, and Past Attendant Kier Robinson.Aidan was a pupil at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh before attending St Davidrsquos High School in Dalkeith. On leaving school, he was appointed as an apprentice with Slight Joinery Ltd.Claire was born and brought up in Whitecraig, attending Whitecraig Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools. She works at Pinkie Farm Shop as a general assistant and has been a member of Musselburgh Crusaders Riding Club since she was  years old.Abbie, who attended Campie Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, is currently in her final year studying BScApplied Animal Science at Scotlandrsquos Rural University College and she is due to graduate in July.They will lead the Musselburgh Festival which runs from July  to  with a range of events for all the family on offer as well as traditional favourites such as the sashing of the Honest Lad and Lass, and ever-popular Crusaders Chase.Stefanie Talac, secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, said: ldquoNow that the election has been run and our official party is in place, the committee will be focussing on festival week itself."We have a few changes to the week following feedback in . This year will see the kirkin move back to am in St Michaelrsquos with the sashing taking place at approximately .pm at the Mall.ldquoOur Family Fun Day will now be on Saturday, July , in Pinkie St Peterrsquos playing fields. This event was a huge success last year and we wish to build on that. Lewisvale proved to be constrictive in size and, due to the vast number of families who attended, we felt that a bigger space was necessary for safety.She added: ldquoThe Saturday is also festival day which we wish to make a focus for the townrsquos celebrations. The treasure hunt which has previously taken place on the Monday will now take place on the Wednesday morning.ldquoThese moves look to ensure that we still have family friendly events spread over the week and allow the official party to attend these as well as the ious visits to nurseries, care homes and local businesses throughout the week."Festival week will run from Saturday, July , until Sunday, July , with a wide iety of events to hopefully suit everyone.

title: talented-amateur-golfer-bob-walkingshaw-remembered
story: Robert lsquoBobrsquo Walkingshaw passed away peacefully at Haddington Care Home last Wednesday after a long illness.Born in Old Craighall, he moved to Salters Road, Wallyford, at the age of  with his father Bob, mother Isa, brother Ian and sisters Elizabeth and Janet.A former pupil of Musselburgh Grammar School, he worked in the ropery at the former Brunton Wire Works in Musselburgh.Mr Walkingshaw took up golf at the age of six.He honed his skills on the fairways of Musselburgh Golf Club, becoming a scratch golfer. He also went on to become a member of Royal Musselburgh Golf Club and Musselburgh Links, The Old Course.In , Mr Walkingshaw, a former Lothians County player, won all four Musselburgh championships: the Monktonhall closed club event Musselburgh Open on the same course Royal Musselburgh Connaught Cup and championship at the Old Links at the racecourse.He also lted the Scottish seniors title twice at amateur level.His sporting prowess did not stop at golf and he became a semi-professional footballer for Stenhousemuir FC. His football career was cut short when he suffered a dislocated hip resulting from a tackle on the pitch and spent six weeks in hospital.A member of Wallyford Bowling Club, he also enjoyed played at the indoor bowling club at Meadowmill.Mr Walkingshaw cared for his mother at their family home on Salters Road.His sister Elizabeth said that he was known as a local ldquolegend in golfing circles, where he was popular and well respected. He was renowned for being ldquoa true gentleman on and off the course.ldquoHe quietly lived his le, she added.Mr Walkingshaw was married twice and has two daughters, Kristi and Debbie, by his second marriage.A devoted grandfather-of-four, he will be sadly missed by the family, including his brother and two sisters.A funeral service takes place tomorrowat Seafield Crematorium at pm. All are welcome to attend.

title: report-of-hare-coursing-near-humbie

title: tims-tales-a-lion-that-has-no-roar
story: SPRING is well upon us, my favourite time of year. Finally, after what always seems a long wait, the land is alive and the evenings are long.The colours of this time are a big part of the joy. The blossom and explosion of wild flowers really lts my mood and spirit.A big part of this, for me, is the dandelion. Itrsquos a wild flower which decorates almost everywhere at the moment, creating a carpet of yellow which then transforms into white puffballs of flying lsquowishesrsquo.So many people just see this flower as an annoying weed to be mowed away as soon as it rears its head, but I love the way it keeps cheekily popping up in defiance of our attempts to keep nature at bay. Itrsquos one of our native wild flowers and causes no damage like some real invasive plants can, such as rhododendron.And they benefit our wildle so much. Bees and butterflies feed on them and some birds eat the seeds. But the benefits of the dandelion to humans has also long been recognised.A tea-like drink can be made from the roots and leaves or florets. There are dferent recipes, as the whole plant is edible. You can even make dandelion wine.The sap also contains healing properties which help with a range of ailments, especially skin complaints and issues related to digestion. In fact, herbalists will tell you of a range of health benefits attributed to the dandelion, which is packed with antitoxins and vitamins.And, of course, there are many folklore traditions associated with the flower.One I was reminded of this week when introducing the flower to a class of school children was the belief that you will wet the bedyou touch the petals! There is a small truth in this, as eating the leaves may have a diuretic effect.Making a wish and then blowing the parachute-like wisps which carry the seeds is the stuff of my childhood.Make the wish in secret and the wisps will carry it and help make it true. It is said they can also carry thoughts and love to someone you are missing or thinking about.Other uses include finding out how much you are loved, how many children you may have, or how many years you have left!The dandelion can even forecast the weather, as the puffball will close in on itselfit turns dreich. Another name for it is the lsquoshepherdrsquos clockrsquo, because its flower opens soon after sunrise and closes before the sun sets.And so this week I brought some dandelions into classrooms in a school where I am storytelling.Before I introduced the flowers, I gave them a riddle: ldquoA lion that has no roar, with teeth that do not bite, children who fly away, once yellow has turned to white. They eventually got the answer.The name dandelion, it is believed, comes from the French term lsquodent de lionrsquo meaning lionrsquos tooth, a reference to the teeth-shaped leaves.Then we blew the lsquowishesrsquo in the classroom. I was quite taken with the sense of wonder the children displayed . Many of them caught and kept the lsquowishesrsquo for later. It was so simple, yet so magic.ldquoHave you got more  I was asked.ldquoTherersquos plenty outside you can pick at home time, I told them.But as I left the school, I noticed the road verge I had picked the flowers had just been mowed. All the dandelions were gone, along with the other wild flowers, and it looked lsquonice and neatrsquo.Maybewe paused for a moment to wonder at how amazing this simple and common flower is, and the benefits it gives, we would have a dferent attitude towards it.Eating hand-picked and hand-washed dandelion leaves is one way my children will eat greens. If I mix them into a stir fry, they will be eaten too. These flowers are not just an irritating weed, they are one of naturersquos gts.As I left the school at the end of the day, a child came up to me.ldquoLook, I have a wish I caught, he said, as he carefully unfurled his hand. ldquoIrsquom going to use it to send my love to my granddad.

title: work-set-to-start-to-restore-dunbar-east-beach-to-its-former-glory
story: The once-picturesque sandy beach has lost huge amounts of sand to the tides in recent years.Now, planning permission has been given for a scheme which aims to reinvigorate the beach, which used to be a magnet for tourists.Groynes, a breakwater and rock armour are included in the proposal, which was highlighted by ward councillor Norman Hampshire at a meeting of Dunbar Community Council.Mr Hampshire, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for environment, told the Courier: ldquoWe have been working on this project for some time, trying to get a method where we can attract sand back onto the beach again.ldquoThe consultants who have been looking at it have taken some time to come up with this option: a redesign of the groyne and two breakwaters to prevent [the damage caused] when we have a large sea coming in it damages the main wall and drags sand off the beach. These breakwaters are supposed to prevent that from happening.ldquoIf we can get sand onto the beach, it should stay.The plans, submitted and approved by East Lothian Council, include repairing or replacing an existing groyne on the southern end of the beach that has fallen into disrepair.A rock groyne will be created at the northern end of the beach, opposite the junction with The Vennel, with a concrete groyne towards the south, while a rock breakwater will also be included.The work is split into four sections, with the refurbishment of the existing groyne acting to retain the beach level in the area as it is currently.Secondly, the breakwater, in addition to providing direct protection to a limited section of the defence, will allow an assessment of the capacity for a natural beach to be developed.The groyne at the northern end of the beach will provide protection over part of the northern section of the seawall, with the potential to develop a higher beach in front of the wall.Finally, armour stones will be put in place along Lamer Street to protect the seawall.Mr Hampshire said time had been taken to find the design most likely to boost the beach.But he added: ldquoThere are no guarantees ndash we are fighting against nature here.Mr Hampshire told community councillors he was hopeful work could start ldquoearly summer.Discussions have been ongoing for more than five years regarding what can be done to try to turn the clock back and see the beach looking as it did in the past.Previous suggestions have included bringing sand across from Crail and St Monans in Fe.Mr Hampshire said that had not been ruled out ndash and every option would be explored ndash but it would prove ldquoreally expensive.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, thanked Mr Hampshire for his efforts in bringing the scheme forward.She stressed the importance of the beach and said: ldquoI think East Beach is just part of the place that Dunbar is.ldquoIt has been a holiday destination for a long time and people remember it as a sandy place and a place of leisure.ldquoThis rocky quarry we have now is something that saddens a lot of people.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said they were not yet in a position to reveal the cost of the scheme.She added: ldquoWork identied as helping to tackle erosion concerns on the East Beach will go out to tender with a view to work starting later this year, hopefully before the autumn period.

title: knox-academy-pupils-and-staff-team-up-for-edinburgh-marathon
story: A team of  will represent Knox Academy at the Edinburgh Marathon Festival in the half marathon.Eleven pupils and eight members of staff will all pull on special t-shirts highlighting that they are running for East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme .Alex Redford, a modern studies teacher at the school, said they were looking forward to taking to the start line on May .He said: ldquoS have really tried to embody the school values of Ambition, Respect and Community this year.ldquoThey have worked so very hard on ious fundraisers throughout the year and it has been great to see them really engage with the school values.Pupils Matthew Black, Dylan Brotherston, Isabelle Bowen, Elliot Cochrane, Harry Cunningham, Hana Elder, Adam Fairgrieve, Mateusz Juchniewicz, Max Leveque, Daniel Mackinnon and Lauren Taylor will be joined on the start line by Lana Borwick , Robert Flood , Susanne Fox , Steven Illingworth , Adam Miller , Thomas Salkeld , Suzie Stewartand Mr Redford.Pupil Dylan said: ldquoThere is a little bit of friendly rivalry between the pupils.ldquoObviously, we are all quite competitive with each other and we are quite close friends. We go training together and there is competitiveness there.ldquoWe would expect to finish before the staff ndash except Miss Borwick, she is fairly fit, we would take being beaten by her!Mr Redford came up with the idea of running the .-mile course and got in touch with fellow members of staff.He said: ldquoA couple of years ago, I decided I would run the half marathon.ldquoThis year, I just thought it would be nice, rather than personal charities, to try to tie in with the school.ldquoI wanted to seeanybody wanted to join me, it was a punt in the dark, and wanted to see whether any other staff or S pupils wanted to do it.ldquoEveryone was really keen.Runners will set off from Potterrow in Edinburgh before winding their way through the city and finally to East Lothian.S pupil Dylan said training was going well and told the Courier how he had been inspired by the charity, which provides full-day playschemes during school holidays for East Lothian children aged five to  with a wide range of special needs or disabilities.He said: ldquoObviously, the charity is really worthwhile. My personal motivation is seeing the work the charity has done with pupils in the school.Exhausted, athletes will cross the finish line at the playing fields at Pinkie in Musselburgh.Dylan added: ldquoIt is nice to be able to run in an environment that is familiar.ldquoHopefully, a few staff and pupils will be coming to support us at the end. When we have done these runs in the past, the support the community offers is brilliant and spurs you on.ldquoIt is nice to be in a local environment.In total, the Knox Academy teachers and pupils are aiming to raise more than pound,, with each runner tasked with collecting at least pound of sponsorship.Donate at justgiving fundraising knoxacademy

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-conservative-candidate-craig-hoy
story: In a -year career in the media and in business, he worked in Edinburgh, London and Asia.He said: ldquoLocal people want a councillor who will focus on everyday issues that matter to everyone in the ward."While the SNP obsesses about another isive independence referendum, I am focusing on local services such as schools, social care, leisure facilities and roads. I will work hard to protect the interests of rural communities."I want to see our High Street flourish and will explore efforts to increase peak-time parking. I will also support action to combat anti-social behaviour in the town centre and beyond."We are welcoming many new residents and I will work hard to ensure schools, doctors surgeries and leisure services are expanded."I will fight SNP Government budget cuts, which this year resulted in East Lothian Council being forced to scrap free music tuition for our children and led to large council tax rises."Regardless of how you normally vote, please lend me your support to stop the SNP winning."If elected, I will be a councillor for everyone in the ward.

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-liberal-democrat-candidate-stuart-crawford
story: His three children all went to school here.He said: ldquoI joined the Scottish Liberal Democrat Party because it is broad-minded, tolerant and inclusive, and above all  believes in decentralisation of political power: local issues demand solutions decided at the local level."I have worked for myself since my Army days and continue to do so, as a political and media consultant and freelance journalist."Previous involvement in local issues includes the setting up of the Sidegate Residentsrsquo Association in the early noughties to campaigningagainst an unsympathetic development on Briery Bank. I have also been recently appointed a trustee of St Maryrsquos Pleasance Garden."East Lothian has been good to me and my family, and now I have the time and energy to give something back."I believe I have a good grasp of what folk tell me needs doing and,elected, representing and serving those in the ward to the best of my ability, and not indulging in petty party politicking, will be my main and only focus.

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-labour-candidate-neal-black
story: He said: ldquoI am proud to live in the ward with my family. I am involved in my community in this way because I care passionately about helping to get the best for local people."We have great schools and other excellent public services which I will defend from sustained Scottish Government cuts."I want to ensure we keep supporting local communities by constantly improving all our vital local services."I am also committed to working with local communities and my Labour colleagues on the council to make our area an even better place to live. This includes promoting physical and mental wellbeing by supporting local sports clubs and being a champion for training and job opportunities for young people."I can think of no greater honour than having the opportunity to serve the community where I was born and have lived my whole le."If you put your faith in me on May , I promise to be a strong local representative who will always act in the interests of the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-everything-you-need-to-know

title: work-about-to-start-on-second-platform-at-dunbar-railway-station
story: Engineers start work on site on Tuesday and are beginning by establishing a project office and compound ahead of the start of construction work at the station.The pound million scheme will deliver a new -metre second  and a fully accessibly steel footbridge, with lts also included for disabled access.Throughout May, work will take place to clear vegetation and redundant buildings and track to make way for the new infrastructure.Construction work on the project will be ongoing from until early next year, with the new  expected to be operational from the end of November.Matthew Spence, Network Rail route delivery director for Scotland, said: ldquoThe new  will mean extra capacity at Dunbar and create opportunities for more services to stop in the future.ldquoThe new infrastructure, which will be fully accessible, will also include a choice of materials and paint colours that are designed to be considerate to the historic station building.The new  will provide increased capacity and improve operational flexibility as currently all northbound and southbound services have to use the same .Northbound stopping services will use the new  once it is constructed and it will also allow train companies on the East Coast Main Line to operate more services on the route in the future.Currently, there are no plans for a pedestrian link to the new  from the south side of the town, although East Lothian Council is keen to see that changed in the future.Two public drop-in sessions were held earlier this year in Dunbar to give members of the public the chance to see the plans for the , near the townrsquos Salisbury Walk.More information on the project can be found at networkrail DunbarStation

title: bridge-over-north-berwick-railway-line-due-to-re-open
story: The bridge over the railway line at Ware Road - where traffic lights are to be installed -has been closed for several days to allow project excavation work to take place.An East Lothian Council spokesperson told the Courier that the first phase of the bridge works, which has led to its closure, was due to be completed today ."To allow the work to be undertaken safely, the bridge has been closed to traffic and pedestrians, with advisory signs in place," said the spokesperson."It ishoped that the first phase,which involved excavation work and the installation of ducting for the traffic signals, will be completed today."The second phase of the works - the installation of the traffic lights - will then start and is expected to take a few days."The bridge will be open during this [second phase] work with traffic management in place," added the spokesperson.The bridge is a key route to school for children and used regularly by motorists as it is the only crossing over the railway line in North Berwick.But its narrowness has led to pedestrian safety concerns as it does not have a raised pavement.East Lothian Council told the Courier last month thatthe introduction of "controlled traffic signals"wouldaid "safer crossing opportunities for pedestrians" - though fears have been raised that the lights will cause a backlog of traffic on Ware Road itself and Old Abbey Road.

title: residents-urged-to-share-their-experiences-of-transport-in-east-lothian
story: East Lothian Council has launched a survey of issues surrounding travel in the county, looking mainly at the A and East Coast Main Line, where the majority of journeys are made.The council has brought in consultants Peter Brett Associates to gather evidence to support any changes to ldquomaximise the integration of sustainable transport options in the area.They have been asked to focus on the best ways to make the most of land use and transport ahead of future development in the county, such as the new town at Blindwells and at the former Cockenzie Power Station site.The consultation will initially focus on the problems people have faced and ask residents what they want to see improved when it comes to travelling in the county.The consultation, which is open on the councilrsquos online consultation hub until next Friday , is, the council said, looking to ldquocapture the opinions and aspirations of local people.ldquoEssentially we would like to understand the transport problems faced by communities and gather views on how the transport network could be improved to provide improved access to employment and services, said a spokesperson.The consultation asks residents to take part in a survey quizzing them about their modes of transport and views on rail and bus travel.ScotRail has come under repeated pressure from East Lothian politicians and campaign groups to improve its services in the county, where the rush-hour service has been dubbed the ldquosardine express due to overcrowding.

title: reduction-in-number-of-new-homes-planned-for-edge-of-macmerry
story: Balfour Beatty revealed plans in November for more than  new homes on the villagersquos western edge.At that time, the development was to be made up of  houses and  flats.However, that has now changed, with  houses and  flats planned for the site, to the north and west of existing houses on Main Road.A spokeswoman for Balfour Beatty said changes in the planned sewage drainage system had resulted in the reduction in the number of homes being proposed.The site would contain  affordable properties, made up of one and two-bedroom flats, as well as two, three and four-bedroom homes.A total of  one-bedroom flats would be created, with eight two-bedroom flats.The affordable housing would be made up of six two-bedroom homes, nine three-bedroom properties and a single four-bedroom house.The remaining houses would be a mix of house styles:  two-bedroom homes,  three-bedroom homes and  four-bedroom detached properties.The development would be accessed by a new road off the A, between the existing properties on the western edge of the village and the road to Adniston Farm.If the plans are approved by East Lothian Council, it will be the second major housing development in Macmerry to be given the go-ahead in recent months.Last September,  houses and eight flats on land to the north of St Germains Terrace were approved.Maureen Cuthill, chairwoman of Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Council, stressed she had no issue about housing being added to the village but was concerned that improvements to infrastructure were not matching the pace of development.She said: ldquoI just think the whole of East Lothian is getting overwhelmed with houses.ldquoTaylor Wimpey is going to build, then Balfour Beatty is going to build and there is just one shop in the village.

title: drink-driver-found-with-metal-bar
story: Police attended at the home of Keith Groom after he was suspected of drink-drivingon the townrsquos Belhaven Road last year.Groom was found to have mcg of alcohol in ml of breath ndash more than three times the legal limit of mcg.During the incident, Groom, of Warrender Crescent, was also found to be in possession of an offensive weapon, namely a metal bar.The -year-old appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Friday.He admitted being in possession of the metal bar but denied drink-driving. However, he was found guilty of the offence following a trial.Groom was handed an interim driving ban and will be fully sentenced on May .Groom admitted being in possession of a metal bar at Belhaven Road on September  last year. He was also found guilty of driving a vehicle with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at the same location and on the same date.

title: key-route-to-and-from-haddington-tesco-to-shut-for-two-weeks
story: Three-way temporary traffic lights were previously in place at a section of Newton Port between Fortune Avenue and Calders Lawn - the access road to Tesco - ahead of the closure.But starting from todayand continuing until nextFriday, the section of road has now been closed completely while footpath repairs take place. A signed ersion is in place.Southbound traffic is being erted via Victoria Park, Lydgait, Hope Park, Court Street and Market Street to enter Newton Port from the south.Northbound traffic is being erted via Market Street, Hardgate, Dunbar Road, Herdmanflatt, Florabank Road and Victoria Park .Footpath repairs started today on Newton Port, Haddington from Calders Lawnto the junction with Fortune Avenue. title: ross-high-school-launches-tobacco-free-school-policy
story: The school is already a non-smoking zone, but this new policy will go further by both recognising the need to provide effective education on tobacco and health, and offering smokers support to quit.Stop smoking support will be available for both pupils and staff who do smoke and, since its launch, some pupils have already positively engaged with that support.The policy applies to all people using the school site including staff, pupils, customers, visitors, contractors and hirers of the building.Ross High has been working with ASH Scotlandand NHS Lothian to develop the policy and is working to send a strong message promoting the health of students, staff and visitors.More than  per cent of Scotlandrsquos secondary schools have so far achieved tobacco-free status.Paul Reynolds, headteacher at Ross High School, said: ldquoKnowing that two-thirds of smokers started before they were , we decided that our vision was of a school where it was normal not to smoke.ldquoWe will strive to give our students an effective education that equips them to make positive choices on tobacco and an environment that supports their right to remain free from addiction.ldquoRoss High School is proud to do our bit in creating a smoke free Scotland.The Scottish Government hopes to create a tobacco-free generation of Scots by .

title: headteacher-chosen-for-newly-merged-primary-school-in-prestonpans
story: The new school is a merger of Prestonpans Primary School and Prestonpans Infant  Nursery School.Neither of the current headteachers ndash Sheila Laing from Prestonpans Infant School and Jonathan Revell of Prestonpans Primary ndash applied for the new position.East Lothian Council has now announced that the post has been given to Alison Cookson and she will take up the role in August.Fiona Robertson, head of education with the council, said: ldquoAlison Cookson is an experienced headteacher who has most recently worked as the interim chief executive Officer to Salford Academy Trust [in Greater Manchester].ldquoShe joins Prestonpans at an important stage in the schoolrsquos development and will lead a transition group involving staff, parents and pupils to establish one learning community from early years through to P.Sheila Laing is staying with the council ndash she is taking up a new lsquovirtual headteacherrsquo post in the county for looked-after and care experienced young people, starting in August.Ms Robertson added: ldquoThe virtual headteacher post is a first for East Lothian and follows successful pilots in other areas, including Aberdeen.ldquoThis is an important role to champion the needs of care experienced young people and ensure that they receive support to improve their le experiences and educational outcomes.ldquoIt will involve working with a wide range of key partners, young people, carers and agencies to develop and implement a strategy to put in place the best possible outcomes for care experienced pupils.ldquoI am delighted that we have appointed Sheila to this role and that her enthusiasm, professionalism and experience will support and drive forward this important work.The virtual headteacher role is funded for two years through Scottish Attainment Challenge Funding.

title: national-retailers-eyeing-up-retail-park-spots-in-haddington
story: The national chains are central to proposals for three retail units and two cafes restaurants at Gateside West.Developer EPICLtd has lodged plans with East Lothian Council for the currently vacant site and members of the public can have their say on the proposals.If approved, about  jobs would be created at the retail park, with a further  construction jobs during the building process.The site, previously earmarked as a Sainsburyrsquos supermarket, is sandwiched between the A and B, with the Oak Tree junction of the A to the west, and would become home to nearly  parking spaces.A diagram showing the layout of the proposed retail park at Gateside West. The three retail units and two cafe restaurants are shaded light blue, with the car park shaded grey. The white space to the west of the car park is earmarked for a petrol stationThe developers are hopeful that work could begin on the site later this year, with a view to businesses being open in summer .A planning and retail statement states: ldquoThe end occupiers are confirmed as Aldi and Home Bargains for the retail and Costa for the restaurant cafe unit.ldquoThe other [two] occupiers are still to be confirmed.A second, separate application for a petrol station, with shop, in the south-west corner of the site has also been submitted by EPICLtd and Euro Garages Ltd.Drawings show four petrol pumps, with toilets within the shop.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents Haddington, was keen to see development take place on the site, which he described as ldquoa blank, empty space.He said: ldquoObviously, I am very sympathetic towards to the town centre and work closely with them but hopefully the idea is the more people we can attract to the town the better.ldquoThe job will be getting them to go into the town centre to use the shops there.ldquoOverall, I am hoping it does not have a drastic effect on their businesses.ldquoThey are the heart of Haddington and have been for a long time. The last thing anybody would want to do is affect their business or status in the town.Fellow ward councillor Provost John McMillan is part of the planning committee, which could ultimately decide the fate of the proposals, so was unable to comment.The developer purchased the site, which measures about , square feet, in February last year and has been working to draw up proposals for the land.A sign recently appeared at the site suggesting that a new retail development was ldquocoming soon.Paul Darling, planning liaison officer with Haddington and District Community Council, felt that a number of concerns raised during the public consultation last year had been listened to by the developer.Comments had been made about how the development would impact upon the existing town centre businesses, as well as the appearance and size of the units on-site.Mr Darling echoed Mr Trotterrsquos comments and said it was important the businesses in the town were able to ldquodrag people into the town centre.Joanna Gibson, chairwoman of Haddington Business Community Partnership , felt that time would tell whether the proposed retail park would impact on the town centre.She said: ldquoMy view is that we are already seeing lots of new faces in the town, which is really positive.We need to encourage people from the new houses into the town to let them experience all the great shops, cafes and services we have to offer.ldquoOnly time will tell whether or not the retail park will have an effect on trade but what does worry me personally is the threat of reduced parking in the town centre, possible introduction of parking charges and free parking at the new retail space.Spokespeople for the three businesses were tight-lipped about any potential interest in the site. Costa declined to comment while the application was in the planning stages, while Aldi said the store was ldquonot currently on our radar, despite the planning statement saying otherwise.

title: pictures-walk-with-scott-2019-raises-huge-total
story: The Walk With Scott Foundation, based in Tranent, is close to reaching a cumulative total of pound, after raising more than pound, after its seventh sponsored walk around the county.More than  people turned out to complete the .-mile walk around East Lothian in aid of the foundation, which ploughs the money that it raises back into good causes in the community.Scott Glynn, founder of the charity, said: ldquoIt was absolutely fantastic, a really incredible day. So many brave people turned up to take part.ldquoWith the online fundraiser page and through cheques and donations, I am optimistic that we are going to go higher than the pound, mark when all the money is collected, which means we will hit pound, as a total raised by the charity.The weather held out for the walkers, with only a few light showers throughout the day.The group set out from Cockenzie, heading to Musselburgh they followed the River Esk to Whitecraig, then went along the old Pencaitland railway, on to Boggs Holdings, up through Butterdean Woods, then along to Longniddry before turning back along the coast road to Cockenzie.Scott, , was happy to be involved this year after a health scare two years ago when he was diagnosed with liver cancer, before he underwent a le-saving transplant.He added: ldquoThe last small section, between Port Seton Harbour and Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion, we were piped along by a piper to the finishing point. Along the route there was the Clark Community Choir singing us on and at another stop there was the local pipe band. It was really incredible ndash a truly brilliant day.As well as sponsorship forms, buckets were carried on the day to allow passers-by to donate, including spectators at Musselburgh Rugby s.Scott said: ldquoWe actually popped along to the s game to seewe could rattle our buckets a wee bit and we raised pound from that section alone! All the money goes back into the community: no-one who helps the charity takes a salary or anything.Karen Kidd, treasurer, secretary and board member, said: ldquoHuge thanks to all who have sponsored and supported our lsquoScottersrsquo for this yearrsquos walk. There is still time to donate by visiting the website.ldquoIrsquove walked all seven walks and have to say that this was up there as being the best so far.ldquoThe pace was great, the group pretty much stuck together for the whole  hours ndash which made the whole experience very enjoyable. Great banter and sing-songs from the walkers, with lovely wee surprises along the route including cupcakes from Sweet Boutique in Prestonpans and lots more.The excess water and fruit from the day has been donated by the foundation: the water going to Tranent Coltsrsquo football tournament and the fruit to Fundamental Foods.Karen said: ldquoOn behalf of the foundationrsquos board, Colin McGinn, Blair Stewart, Alan Bell and myself, we would like to say a huge thank you to all of this yearrsquos Scotter family for helping us continue to help others across our communities.Simon Davie, Farsquoside Area Partnership manager, took part and said: ldquoThe atmosphere and camaraderie was amazing. I met some fantastic people and was humbled by some of their stories ndash all there putting their bodies on the line to make a dference for our local communities. It was a truly inspiring day with a truly inspiring leader.The Walk with Scott Foundation was founded seven years ago after Scott did his very first walk and has gone from strength to strength, donating to a number of local causes.Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, said: ldquoScottrsquos fundraising over the last few years has become legendary, and to reach pound, in support of a good causes is a remarkable achievement.ldquoHe deserves huge praise for what he has achieved through his foundations, especially considering the personal health battle he has gone through.ldquoHowever, I know he would be the first to acknowledge that none of this could have been achieved without the support and generosity of iniduals and communities across East Lothian.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving WWSFWalk

title: measures-to-control-seagulls-to-be-carried-out-in-two-towns

title: tims-tales-north-berwick-laws-ancient-history
story: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I climbed North Berwick Law, or Berwick Law as many call it, and felt rather ashamed of myself. This was because I had never done it before. I canrsquot quite believe this myself that Irsquove left it to my late s to finally make the conquest.How many times I have said to myself, and my family, as we explored dferent parts of East Lothian, ldquowe must climb North Berwick Law someday as its distinctive shape loomed into view. Itrsquos a hill visible from so many places, just asking to be explored, but I always seemed to put it off. But finally I have done it.Itrsquos a huge pile of igneous rock, basically cooled and solidied lava, a remnant of ancient volcanic activity. Itrsquos a giant plug on a now-extinct volcanic vent. Folklore tradition has a very dferent origin for the hill, as I have already written about.When you stand at the base of the Law and peer up, you can see where the great glaciers of the Ice Age have scraped and polished the hillrsquos surface, making it quite rugged and craggy in places, and smoothed down in others. Itrsquos  feet high, not a mountain by any definition, yet still impressive. If it were in a hilly area we would notice the Law less, but it looms up from flatter landscape, right next to the sea, and so demands attention.No wonder it became a place of human settlement in the Iron Age period. How could you not use this hill as a location for a fort  Its steep, rocky braes are perfect for defence, itrsquos next to the sea with a ldquoview of the whole world, as my four-year-old put it ndash and was not entirely wrong!Cast your eye to the north and across the Firth was the land of the Picts. The open sea can be seen to the north east and almost the entire of East Lothian is laid out before you, to the Lammermuirs in the south and the Pentlands in the west.Here was the land of the Gododdin, the Celtic people who lived in our country when the Romans arrived, although they had a dferent name for them: the Votadini. They survived the Roman presence, perhaps entering into some alliance to preserve their tribe. The Romans were ruthless with those who did not co-operate and submit.But later, in the seventh century, long after the Romans had gone, the Angles arrived from the south. The Gododdin resisted the invasion. The great early poem Y Gododdin tells us of a great assemblage of warriors who feasted at Edinburgh before heading south to their deaths in battle.What wailing and sadness there must have been when the news of the loss of all those young, handpicked warriors arrived. The Goddodinsrsquo fate was soon sealed, the Angles took control of the land and the Lothians became part of the Northumbrian kingdom. The remnants of the disposed Gododdin migrated to Wales, it seems, taking with them their stories and legends of what became known as lsquothe old northrsquo.These were my thoughts as I found the remains on an old round house as we climbed to the summit of the Law. At first I wasnrsquot sure ndash it looked almost like a small standing stone circle ndash but on closer examination I realised the stones were the foundations of a Celtic round house. An archaeologist friend later confirmed this.There are at least  Iron Age round houses or similar structures so far discovered on the Law some are less obvious. Butyou carefully study the ground as you ascend, evidence of these ancient homes can be seen. There is also evidence of old walls or ramparts.So here a community of the Gododdin once lived. From their front doors they could see their sister forts of Dun Penderbut now named Traprain Law, and Din Eidyn, later to be called Edinburgh.So I entered the circle of stones as my kids played on a rock nearby. I was now in a space where once a family might have lived. It was not large, but then again, why would it be  It was a place to sleep and sit round the fire together. No need to make space for all the modern lsquonecessitiesrsquo of le. Their le would have been lived outdoors. But what stories were told in this intimate space, what lives were led, and when was the last night this was used as a home There is lots more to the history of North Berwick Law. The watch house from the Napoleonic period, the observation bunker from the Second World War and, of course, the whale bones, which are now made of fibreglass. All these connect to stories that make up the history of this fascinating wee hill.But for me on that day, it was the walk through prehistory, and the mysterious remains from an ancient Celtic people, that left my imagination tingling.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland really is leading the way on climate change  but it won t be a walk in the park
story: Therersquos some doubt, according to the science journal Nature, about just how effective tree planting is as a means of combating global warming. Trees emit chemicals too, and darken the land, thus absorbing heat. But letrsquos not quibble. The Committee on Climate Changewhich inspired last weekrsquos landmark target, is in no doubt that mass reforestation ndash and wersquore talking billions of trees ndash will be one of the major methods of scrubbing CO from the atmosphere.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeScotland is well placed to deliver on this at least. Those barren hills and glens used to be under a dense covering of foliage. The forests were cleared for agriculture and charcoal in the south, and latterly for sheep and deer in the north. So mass forestation is only restoring the ecological default in Scotland.Nice to know, too, that Scotland, on paper at least, is leading the way on meeting climate change targets, having reduced emissions by a creditable % since . This is better than the UK as a whole, which is itself a world-leader in climate control. Scotlandrsquos abundant renewable energy is going to play a major role in transforming the UK economy.Transport is one of the main areas yet to be decarbonised, and every watt of that green energy is needed to make the switch from petrol and diesel in the next decade. Itrsquos long overdue. The internal combustion engine is th-century technology, horribly complex, unreliable and inefficient. Future generations will be astonished that we allowed our city streets to remain sewers of toxic chemicals.Mind you, the Scottish Government needs to put its foot on the environmental accelerator pedal. It is three years since I wrote a series of articles on electric cars after being allowed to drive some of them around Scotland. There were precious few charging points back then, and therersquos scarcely any more now. Yet, the electrication of transport should be a relatively simple exercise.Every petrol station should be a charging station, every supermarket car park, every school and hospital. Wherever cars congregate, in fact. The good news is that no-one who tries a modern electric car will want to drive anything , because they are faster, cheaper, safer and more reliable.Of course, manufacturing any car uses prodigious amounts of energy too, requires many costly materials and produces toxic waste. Electric cars arenrsquot a solution to climate change, but electrication of transport must be, especially micro-transportation. Every city in Europe seem to be turning to those electric scooters ndash except in the UK where they are illegal. Half of the bicycles sold in Germany now are electric. People are turning naturally to more energy-efficient transport so why not give them a push :Climate clock is ticking and now is time for politicians to fightThe CCC report was rather benign on flying. Yoursquoll be pleased to know that itrsquos not being phased out. This is probably because reducing aviation requires international agreement. However, cuts in air passenger duty seem dficult to justy. The Scottish Government wants APD cut by % to attract more business and tourists to Scotland. But Nicola Sturgeon is going to have to bite the environmental bullet here. The optics are wrong. It looks too much like a middle-class subsidy, even though many working-class people swear by Ryanair.Then therersquos the nuclear conundrum. Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations account for % of electricity generation ndash a large proportion of our nominally clean energy. But they are old and unreliable and in need of replacement. However, nuclear power stations are regardedas a safety issue following Fukushima. They are also ruinously expensive and damage the environment by producing toxic waste which needs to be stored for thousands of years.The nuclear industry leapt upon last weekrsquos CCC report as a vindication of nuclear as part of the de-carbon equation. Big money is going into painting the atom green. But the prospect of the Scottish Government commissioning a new nuclear plant, given the explosive cost of Hinkley Point C, Englandrsquos first new nuclear power station in decades, seem remote. Renewable energy is much cheaper, joule for joule,it can be brought to grid fast enough. We are in a race against time to seeTorness and Hunterston can be made redundant before they fall apart.There are other issues too. Homes need to be insulated, gas boilers are going to have to go. Wersquore told to keep our home thermostats at  degrees, when most of us donrsquot have them. Itrsquos all expected to cost -% of GDP. But what was remarkable about last weekrsquos much-anticipated report was how doable it all appeared. By comparison with the apocalyptic forecasts of the climate Cassandras, like -year-old school striker Greta Thunberg, the CCC sounded like a walk in the environmental park. Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.

title: us-bid-to-oust-board-at-scots-bus-and-rail-giant
story: Activist investor Coast Capital, which has built up its stake in FirstGroup to . per cent, has accused the current leadership of presiding over a ldquotrack record of value destruction and under-performance at the Aberdeen headquartered firm.:Transport giant faces demand for leadership cullAnd it raised the prospect of selling off parts of the group in order to ldquocreate value for shareholders, employees and pensioners. FirstGroup operates Greyhound, First Student and First Transit in the US, as well as First Bus and First Rail, which runs three major rail franchises in the UK, in its home market.:FirstGroup stock market worth tumbles after US suitor departsDeclaring that the value of FirstGroup has plunged by % since , the activist is demanding an extraordinary general meeting at which shareholders would be asked to vote to remove six of the current eleven directors. These include chief executive Matthew Gregory, who succeeded Tim OrsquoToole in November, and chairman Wolfhart Hauser.Coast is calling for the removal of non-executive directors Steve Gunning, Martha Poulter, Imelda Walsh and James Winestock, while proposing the appointment of seven its own nominees, whom it says are independent and have ldquorelevant transport and turnaround credentials.Among its nominees are former UK transport minister Steve Norris and David Martin, a one-time chief executive of bus giant Arriva.:Scottish transport giant knocks back US takeover approachAskedthere was any particular aspect of FirstGrouprsquos performance that Coast was unhappy with, partner Chad Tappendorf claimed one-third of First Bus routes in the UK are unprofitable, while two of its three rail franchises are running at a loss. He added that First Transit and First Student underperform rival National Express, the second biggest player in these markets behind FirstGroup, by ldquotwo or three percentage points.Mr Tappendorf said: ldquoThere is meaningful room for improvement across the entire portfolio. We are not trying to step on anybodyrsquos toes. What we are trying to do is put in place the very best board members to lead this company to its full and fair valuation, which is in the best interests of not just shareholders, but all stakeholders.:First Glasgow launches new state-of-the-art buses on airport serviceAsked whether Coast,successful, would look to sell assets, Mr Tappendorf said: ldquoSeventy per cent of its operating income is through the US businesses. There are ways to meaningfully improve the business... but at the end of the day this is a company that operates five dferent businesses across seven times zones, all centrally located in the UK. That is a very dficult position to be in.:FirstGroup boss faces investor rebellion at AGMCoast said it has a long track record of making suggestions to improve the firmrsquos performance, which have been ignored. Chief investment officer and partner James Rastehsaid it has a long-term commitment to the company, noting it had defended it against a takeover approach from Apollo, the US private equity firm, last year. ldquoIf we were short-term opportunists we would have tried to get maximum price and just get on, he said.FirstGroup said it has the right team in place and has responded to suggestions from the investor. It said: ldquoThe board of FirstGroup are focused on delivering shareholder value and are confident that the company has the right team with the right experience and plans in place to do so. The board regularly reviews its composition to ensure it maintains an appropriate balance of skills and expertise, and new board members have been added, as recently as earlier this month.The company added: ldquoFirstGroup considers the views of all shareholders and, accordingly, will continue to engage with Coast Capital having attempted to do so constructively for more than a year.Shares closed down .p, or .%, at .p.

title: holyrood-does-not-express-definitive-view-on-scotlands-future-david-mundell-insists
story: In an exclusive interview with The Herald to mark the th anniversary of the creation of the new Scottish Parliament, the Scottish Secretary is adamant that refusing to concede to Nicola Sturgeonrsquos call for a second vote on the nationrsquos future is fully in line with the devolved settlement.When it is suggested that refusing the First Ministerrsquos demand ndash mandated by MSPs in March  ndash for so-called ldquoindyref is not respecting Britainrsquos system of devolution, Mr Mundell disagrees and declares: ldquoYes, it is.:David Mundell urges Jeremy Corbyn to seal Brexit dealldquoBecause the responsibility for constitutional matters, such as holding a referendum, rests with the UK Government as part of the devolution settlement and, therefore, while the Scottish Parliament has the right to ask for a referendum - and I fully respect that right - we have the right to say No.When it is also put to him that Holyrood believes it represents the will of the Scottish people but he does not, the Secretary of State replies: ldquoNohellipScotland has two parliaments, it has two governments. The basis for a referendum was well-documented in .Askedit is, therefore, up to the UK Parliament to decide the limits of devolution, Mr Mundell tells The Herald: ldquoI donrsquot recognise the way in which you are construing that because devolution means that certain matters are the responsibility of the Scottish Parliament, so like education and health, these are almost a full responsibility.ldquoI put through orders in this Parliament to ensure that policies I donrsquot agree with in Scotland are in force free prescriptions, I didnrsquot agree with that policy at that time. I have put through the orders in this Parliament in relation to devolved matters even though I donrsquot agree with them because I accept the Scottish Parliament has responsibility. On the constitution, it is a matter that is reserved to the Westminster ParliamenthellipldquoThe Scottish Parliament is entitled to express an opinion and a view in relation to other matters but it is not the definitive view of Scotland.The Cabinet minister explains how the nature of devolution means it has limits. ldquoI have never suggested devolution is independence itrsquos not. The judgement the people of Scotland made was: yes devolution of the issues and subsequent issues is the way forward because we have benefited from having two parliaments and from the best of both worlds as it is sometimes construed.Tony Blair: Scotland is right to stay in EU but it would be wrong to leave the UKMr Mundell expresses concern about how voters and, indeed, politicians conflate the Scottish Parliament with the Scottish Government the public mindset, he believes, needs to change.ldquoMost people who have negativities towards the Scottish Parliament, what they mean is they donrsquot like the Scottish Government. Whereas here at Westminster, despite all its flawshellippeople donrsquot think John Bercow is running the country. They understand the House of Commons is dferent from Theresa May and her Government. We havenrsquot sufficiently been able to dferentiate the Scottish Parliament as an institution[from the Scottish Government].Noting how no one is to blame for this situation, he says: ldquoMy dear friend Michael Russell, I have had to pull him up many times in discussions he has had here where he says the Scottish Parliament this and the Scottish Parliament that and he means the Scottish Government. They can conflate the two.ldquoThe Parliament is dferent from the Government and for us the institution develops, grows, matures. All of these additional powers and responsibilities it is taking on or will eventually take on, when the Scottish Government can get round to dealing with them, we need to see that dferentiation so people think the Parliament is dferent from the people who are running the Government.The Scottish Secretary admits that the Conservatives, who vehemently opposed devolution before the  referendum fearing a Yes vote could break up the Union, should have been quicker to accept the new settlement, which was voted for by nearly  per cent of Scotland on a  per cent turnout.He claims the Tories made a ldquoperfectly legitimate case in opposing devolution but ldquoonce it had become clear it was the settled will of the Scottish people, that it was going to happen, it would have been better to have accepted that earlier.:Sir John Curtice: Devolution was supposed to kill nationalism stone dead - its very much aliveMr Mundell, who has held his Cabinet post since , goes on: ldquoI always pay tribute to David McLetchie[the late Scottish Conservative leader] because what he did was as a leader he took us into that Parliament and acted in a combative but a constructive way and the  Tory MSPs who were elected in  and all their successors have always embraced and worked for that Parliament and for devolution. Once the referendum decision had been made, they completely put behind their previous position.The -year-old MP for or Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale makes clear Holyrood has now established itself as part of Scottish le but its potential has been unfulfilled, not because of the Parliament itself but because of the governments since .ldquoThe initial Labour-Liberal Governments were dull they didnrsquot take any risks really in terms of what they did. The smoking ban was probably the biggest challenge to orthodoxy that took place and I commend the Parliament for that decision.ldquoSince [when the SNP took power] the constitution has ultimately dominated, he complains, claiming the Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon administrations have held back the development of Scottish devolution.ldquoEducation is the biggest indictment, declares Mr Mundell. ldquoIf,  years ago as we took our oath, people would have said after  years of this Parliament there would be more young people leaving school without any qualications at all, people would have been stunned.ldquoThey believed as I did that this Parliament was about enhancing and taking forward Scottish education and its traditions and its dferences and making it even better and that has not happened.ldquoI put a large part of that down to  years when the Scottish Parliament has spent focusing entirely on and such a big part of its emotional effort on the constitution. Itrsquos unfulfilled.When it is pointed out how the Tories bang on about the possibility of Scottish independence because the constitution is just as good electorally and politically for them as it is for the SNP, Mundell says: ldquoI can make a commitment right now thatNicola Sturgeon takes independence and another referendum off the table, Irsquoll stop speaking about it. I can give that absolute commitmenthellip Two weeks ago, the First Minister set out how there has to be another referendum, she wants to have a bill and Citizensrsquo Assemblies. I donrsquot want to have any of those things.But The Herald points out Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues would never take independence off the table and he knows it given the SNPrsquos raison drsquoetre is to campaign for an independent Scotland.He adds: ldquoThe SNPrsquos route to independence used to be they would deliver good government people will think we have done such a good job, we should be given the whole responsibility. That has been abandoned because their record on domestic issues has been so poor.

title: msp-says-orange-order-marches-past-catholic-churches-have-gone-on-too-long
story: Ms McNeill said permitting theOrder, and other loyalist organisations marchpast Catholic places of worship had "gone on too long".Her comments come between two silent protests outside Catholic Churches on the route of marchesin Glasgows East End this week.Last weekend a silent demonstration was held outside of St Marys in Calton at the weekend, andanother isplanned by the group Call It Out at St Alphonsus Church on Saturday.
